subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] QS-SAMPA: a proposed format for plain-text Quickscript
msgSnippet: Ted Larson Freeman wrote: Yes, but only for some accents (mine included). I ll restate my earlier conclusion based on focused attention on /yr/ in my own
messageBody:
Ted Larson Freeman wrote:



Yes, but only for some accents (mine included). I'll restate my
earlier conclusion based on focused attention on /yr/ in my own
reading and writing: I think this is a minor issue that is quickly
overcome with a little practice. Given that many people will not have
this issue at all, I think it does not warrant any change in usage.






I don't think that's the case. Both  dictionary.com, and in my Longman dictionary,  list words like NURSE spelled with /3r/. Both dictionaries represent the majority of American speakers.  The Cambridge dictionary lists it the same way. So most people will have this issue. Yes, we can overcome the ambiguity with practice, but then the spelling replicates the mistakes in TO, in which we have to learn by context what sounds letters make, rather than have one unambiguous representation.

Paul
